content:
The facts
The majority of us still have an old boiler, and as yours is over 10 years old, it may be costing you a fortune in heating bills.  The oldest boilers are only 60% efficient at keeping your home warm , and emit more carbon emissions  than the new condensing versions. 
 
What you can do 
Consider replacing your old boiler with a new condensing boiler.  They are over 90% efficient and help keep your home warm and snug
briefTipContent: Upgrade to a condensing boiler and save up to a third on your heating bills

content:
The facts
Are your heating bills burning a hole in your pocket? Turning your thermostat down by just 1degree C can save you 10% on your fuel bill.

What you can do
Try turning your thermostat down gradually by one dgree until you reach a comfortable 19-21 degrees C in your living room, and 18 degrees C in your bedroom.  Also check that your hot water tank termostat or immersion heater has been set to no more than 60 degrees C.  You'll still feel warm and cosy, but as an added bonus each degree drop will save you 10% off your average heating bill.
briefTipContent: Turn your thermostat down by 1 degree if it is set too high and save 10% on your bill
links: <link><linktext>Find out more about high efficiency condensing boilers  </linktext><linkurl>http://www.energysavingtrust.org.uk/home_improvements/heating_and_hot_water/what_is_a_high_efficiency_condensing_boiler</linkurl></link>

content:
The facts
monitoring your fuel bills will help you get a handle on how much your heating is costing you.

What you can do
Start keeping an eye on your fuel bills, and if you have them handy, compare them with older bills to see how much you are spending.  If you find your bills are burning a hole in your pocket try turning the temperature on your thermostat down gradually by one degree until you reach a comfortable 19-21 degrees C in your living room and 18 degrees C in your bedroom.  You'll still feel warm and cosy, but as an added bonus each degree drop will save you 10% off your average heating bill.
briefTipContent: Check your fuel bills for your real energy useage - you might be using less than is estimated
links: <link><linktext>Offers are available to help you save money on installing energy saving measures:</linktext><linkurl>http://www.energysavingtrust.org.uk/what_can_i_do_today/energy_saving_grants_and_offers</linkurl></link>

content: Congratulations for already choosing a 'green / renewable tariff' option.  You are already helping to increase demand for more clean, renewable energy supply in the UK.  However, because, generally, the renewable energy you are using has already been accounted for in the ' UK energy mix', and the carbon intensity (ie the amount of carbon released due to each Kilowatt-hour of energy produced) of our fuel has been calculated to include that renewable supply , we still give you a CO2 rating for your electricity usage.
links: <link><linktext>Find out about generating your own energy:</linktext><linkurl>http://www.energysavingtrust.org.uk/generate_your_own_energy</linkurl></link>

content: Why not look into switching to a Green tariff. There are a number energy companies that offer tariff options that supply renewable electricity to domestic customers. The nature of the physical supply you receive won't change, but you will be helping to support the demand for more renewable energy supply within the UK
briefTipContent: Switch to a green tariff and support renewable energy
links: <link><linktext>Click here to find out more about green electricity:</linktext><linkurl>http://www.energysavingtrust.org.uk/generate_your_own_energy/green_electricity</linkurl></link>

content:
Great news 
By investing in renewable technology in your home you're already reducing your carbon footprint and supporting the development of green technology.
briefTipContent: Well done

content:
The Facts 
Even if you’ve made your home as energy efficient as possible  there is still more you can do. Using renewable sources reduces the energy you use, and as a result, the carbon emissions emitted.

What you can do
Why not look into renewable energy technologies, such as solar hot water, biomass burners or ground source heat pumps.  Installing technology like this could reduce your energy bills and will cut your carbon footprint. Solar hot water heating alone can meet around a third of your hot water needs throughout the year.
briefTipContent: After making your house energy efficient, why not thing about generating your own power through renewable technologies
links: <link><linktext>Find out about generating your own energy:</linktext><linkurl>http://www.energysavingtrust.org.uk/generate_your_own_energy</linkurl></link><link><linktext>Find grants for installing renewable energy, please click here:</linktext><linkurl>http://www.energysavingtrust.org.uk/generate_your_own_energy/grants_for_renewables</linkurl></link>

content: Insulating your home can significantly reduce your utility bills. Here are a few simple suggestions:
briefTipContent: Help to keep your home warm in the following ways:
links: <link><linktext>Find out more about insulating your home:</linktext><linkurl>http://www.energysavingtrust.org.uk/home_improvements/home_insulation_glazing</linkurl></link><link><linktext>See how you could add value to your home:</linktext><linkurl>http://www.energysavingtrust.org.uk/Home-improvements/Moving-Home/Unlock-the-hidden-value-of-your-home</linkurl></link>

content:
The facts 
If your energy bills are slipping out of control, it could be something to do with the heat rising out of your roof . As much as a quarter of the energy you use to heat your house could be escaping out of your loft if you haven't insulated your loft.

What you can do 
Insulating an uninsulated loft is one of the most cost-effective measures of reducing heat loss and it?s really easy to install. Simply insulate your loft to the recommended depth of 270mm, and the average 3-bed semi-detached house could reduce its CO2 emissions by around 940kg per year. Plus, you will save money on your energy bills too.
briefTipContent: Insulate your loft and save 1 tonne of carbon dioxide per year
links: <link><linktext>Click here to find out more about loft insulation:</linktext><linkurl>http://www.energysavingtrust.org.uk/home_improvements/home_insulation_glazing/loft_insulation</linkurl></link><link><linktext>Find Energy Saving Recommended insulation:</linktext><linkurl>http://www.energysavingtrust.org.uk/Compare-and-buy-products/Insulation</linkurl></link>

content:
Great news

If you've already insulated your loft, you're already cutting your footprint by up to 940kg of CO2 every year, provided you've added insulation to at least the recommended depth of 270mm (nearly a foot). If you haven't got this much then you?re probably throwing money down the drain (or up the chimney, out the window etc)- consider topping-up your insulation to at least the recommended depth of 270mm.
links: <link><linktext>Find out about other ways of insulating your home:</linktext><linkurl>http://www.energysavingtrust.org.uk/home_improvements/home_insulation_glazing</linkurl></link><link><linktext>How energy efficient is your home%3F</linktext><linkurl>http://www.energysavingtrust.org.uk/what_can_i_do_today/how_efficient_is_your_home</linkurl></link>

content:
The facts
If your walls aren't insulated, heat could be seeping out of them, which means you're paying for heating that you'll quickly lose. Although insulating your solid walls will be an expense at the start, it's an investment in the value of your house, and with every year that passes it will be saving you money on heating - up to %A3500 a year if you live in a large detached house.

What you can do
Have you considered solid wall insulation for your external walls? This can be fitted on the inside or the outside and can drastically reduce heat lost through the walls. The work can be carried out at any time, but it's particularly worth considering if you're going to be doing some renovation or redecorating.
briefTipContent: Consider having solid wall insulation fitted, if you are renovating your home.
links: <link><linktext>For more information on solid wall insulation click here  </linktext><linkurl>http://www.energysavingtrust.org.uk/home_improvements/home_insulation_glazing/solid_wall_insulation</linkurl></link>

content:
Great news
If you've already installed solid wall insulation, then it's probably saving you up to 2.5 tonnes of CO2 a year. Your heating bills would be a lot higher without it.

The Facts
Around a third of all the heat lost in an un-insulated home escapes through the walls. 

What you can do
You probably have cavity walls.  If so, insulating them will make a great diffrence to keeping your home nice and warm, as well as reducing carbon emissions.  In fact for an average 3-bed semi-detached house this is likely to save around 800 kgs of CO2 per year.
briefTipContent: Fill your cavity walls and save 720kg carbon dioxide / year
links: <link><linktext>For more information on cavity wall insulation click here:</linktext><linkurl>http://www.energysavingtrust.org.uk/home_improvements/home_insulation_glazing/cavity_wall_insulation</linkurl></link>

content:
The facts
If your walls aren't insulated, heat could be seeping out of them, which means you're paying for heating that you'll quickly lose. Although insulating your solid walls will be an expense at the start, it's an investment in the value of your house, and with every year that passes it will be saving you money on heating - up to %A3500 a year if you live in a large detached house.

What you can do
Have you considered solid wall insulation for your external walls? This can be fitted on the inside or the outside and can drastically reduce heat lost through the walls. The work can be carried out at any time, but it's particularly worth considering if you’re going to be doing some renovation or redecorating.
briefTipContent: Consider having solid wall insulation fitted, if you are renovating your home.

content:
Great news
If you've already insulated your walls, you're already typically saving 720kg of CO2 each year. Your heating bills would also be much higher without this insulation.
links: <link><linktext>Find out about other ways of insulating your home:</linktext><linkurl>http://www.energysavingtrust.org.uk/home_improvements/home_insulation_glazing/loft_insulation</linkurl></link>

content:
The facts 
Many older properties were built with suspended wooden floors, meaning that there is a gap between the ground under the house and the surface that you walk on. This space is full of cold air and so can often be a source of cold draughts in your home.

What you can do
If you don't have a fitted carpet, make sure there aren't any big cracks in the floorboards to let cold draughts in. And whether you have fitted carpets or not, you might also like to invest in some under floor insulation. There will be a specialist in your area who can do this for you, so it's something to consider if you?re doing some renovating or redecorating.  You?ll soon notice a change in temperature, and for the average 3-bed semi-detached house the CO2 emissions could be reduced by around 250kg per year.
briefTipContent: Install underfloor heating and save 250kg carbon dioxide / year
links: <link><linktext>Click here to find out more about floor insulation:</linktext><linkurl>http://www.energysavingtrust.org.uk/home_improvements/home_insulation_glazing/floor_insulation</linkurl></link>

content:
Great news 
If you've already installed under floor insulation, this measure means you're already saving around 250kg of CO2 each year
links: <link><linktext>Find out about other ways of insulating your home:</linktext><linkurl>http://www.energysavingtrust.org.uk/home_improvements/home_insulation_glazing/loft_insulation</linkurl></link><link><linktext>Take control of your heating, find out more about heating controls:</linktext><linkurl>http://www.energysavingtrust.org.uk/home_improvements/heating_and_hot_water/heating_controls</linkurl></link>

content:
The facts 
Heat from your home can be lost through old single glazed windows - in fact around 20% can escape through them, leaving you with a bigger heating bill and possibly a chilly home

What you can do 
A quick and effective solution, at least for the winter, is to put up some double glazing film. Have a look for it in your local DIY store or online. A more permanent solution to getting a warmer home is to install glass or Perspex double glazing. By fitting the minimum 'C' rating Energy Saving Recommended (ESR) windows in place of standard windows, the CO2 emissions from the average 3-bed semi-detached house can be cut by around 710kg per year.
briefTipContent: Double glaze your windows and save 710kg carbon dioxide / year
links: <link><linktext>Reduce your CO2 emissions with double glazing:</linktext><linkurl>http://www.energysavingtrust.org.uk/home_improvements/home_insulation_glazing/glazing</linkurl></link>

content:
Great news 
If you've already installed Energy Saving Recommended double glazing, that means you're already saving around 710kg of CO2 each year. Just make sure your doors and windows are properly draught-proofed too!
links: <link><linktext>Have you thought about other ways of insulating your home%3F Click here to find out more:</linktext><linkurl>http://www.energysavingtrust.org.uk/home_improvements/home_insulation_glazing</linkurl></link>

content:
The facts 
If you can feel cold drafts around your windows and doors, it's likely you've got small gaps around their edges that need attention? Blocking up? These small gaps not only allow cold air in, but also let warm air escape, making your home colder than it need be.

What you can do
Draught proofing is one of the simplest and cheapest forms of insulating your home, and can make a big difference to how cosy it feels - and all houses can benefit! A wide range of suitable products are available in DIY stores and they take just a few minutes to apply. Draugh-proofing your windows and doors will improve the temperature of your home, save you money and reduce your CO2 emissions by around 150kg per year.
briefTipContent: Fit draught-proofing around doors and windows
links: <link><linktext>Find out more about draught proofing  </linktext><linkurl>http://www.energysavingtrust.org.uk/home_improvements/home_insulation_glazing/draught_proofing</linkurl></link>

content:
Great news 
If you've already draught-proofed your home by insulating your doors and windows, then you're saving around 150 kg of CO2 every year
links: <link><linktext>Have you thought about other ways of insulating your home%3F Click to find out more:</linktext><linkurl>http://www.energysavingtrust.org.uk/home_improvements/home_insulation_glazing </linkurl></link>

content:
The facts
An average household spends around 20% of its electricity budget on lighting. Using low energy lighting can reduce the amount of energy used in lighting your home by up to 80%.

What you can do
The easiest thing is of course to make sure you turn off lights when you leave the room! But the next step is to replace all bulbs in your house with low energy ones. You can buy them from your local supermarket or DIY store for just a few pounds, and best of all, they?ll last up to 10 times longer than standard light bulbs.
briefTipContent: Fit energy efficient lightbulbs in your most used fittings
links: <link><linktext>Read more about energy saving lighting:</linktext><linkurl>http://www.energysavingtrust.org.uk/energy_saving_products/types_of_energy_saving_recommended_products/lightbulbs_and_fittings</linkurl></link>

content:
Great news 
By replacing over half the bulbs in your home to energy saving ones you're already saving over %A328 a year and over 90kg CO2 - or as much as %A356 and 190kg CO2 if you've replaced them all.

Just make sure your lights are always switched off when nobody is using the room!
links: <link><linktext>Click here for 10 quick and simple energy saving measures:</linktext><linkurl>http://www.energysavingtrust.org.uk/What-can-I-do-today/Getting-started</linkurl></link>

content:
Great news 
You're already saving energy by replacing some of the bulbs in your home to energy saving versions. Why not swap a few more bulbs now and you could save even more CO2.

And of course make sure your lights are always switched off when nobody is using the room!
briefTipContent: You've changed a few bulbs to energy saving ones, why not change the rest too%3F

content:
Great news 
If you've replaced all the bulbs in your house to energy saving versions then you've already saved %A356 and 190kg CO2 this year! 
Now all you need to do to save money and save energy is to make sure you remember to turn them off when you leave the room
briefTipContent: Always turn off the light when you leave a room
links: <link><linktext>Click here for 10 quick and simple energy saving measures:</linktext><linkurl>http://www.energysavingtrust.org.uk/What-can-I-do-today/Getting-started</linkurl></link>

content:
The facts
A 'Real Time Display' (sometimes called a 'wireless energy monitor')  is a small digital display that can talk to your electricity meter and give you an up-to-the-minute display of your electricity consumption.  It will  show you which appliances are using the most energy and can help you  cut out waste. 

What you can do
Think about getting a 'Real Time Display' so you can see how much electricity you are using Some manufacturers claim that keeping an eye on your consumption in this way can result in savings of as much as 20%, although the amount you manage will depend on your circumstances and how you decide to use the display. If you want to get hold of one then try looking on the internet. You may also be able to get one from your electricity supplier.
briefTipContent: Why don't you monitor your electricity use
links: No

content:
The facts
The appliances in our homes can contribute a significant amount to our household CO2 emissions. As some of your appliances are over 12 years old they could be emitting more CO2 than you think and costing you more than they need to. 

What you can do 
If you’re buying or replacing appliances, make sure the new ones are Energy Saving Recommended (ESR). ESR approved appliances are always the most energy efficient in their class and are readily available; just visit your local electrical store and they’ll be able to recommend the best options for you.
briefTipContent: Replace old appliances and save money on runing costs

content:
Great news
If you’ve already bought an Energy Saving Recommended (ESR) cold appliance, you’re already saving up to 137kg of CO2 each year compared to a non-ESR model.
links: <link><linktext>Find other energy efficient products:</linktext><linkurl>http://www.energysavingtrust.org.uk/energy_saving_products/types_of_energy_saving_recommended_products  </linkurl></link>

content:
The facts
The appliances in our homes can contribute a significant amount to our household CO2 emissions. As some of your appliances are over 12 years old they could be emitting more CO2 than you think and costing you more than they need to. 
What you can do 
If you?re buying or replacing appliances, make sure the new ones are Energy Saving Recommended (ESR). ESR approved appliances are always the most energy efficient in their class and are readily available; just visit your local electrical store and they?ll be able to recommend the best options for you.
briefTipContent: Replace old appliances and save money on running costs

content:
The facts
Your fridge is one of the biggest energy users in your house as it’s on the go 24 hours a day, 7 days a week. 
If everyone in the UK swapped to an Energy Saving Recommended (ESR) version we could save around £800 million and 2.8 million tonnes CO2.

What you can do
Simply upgrading to an ESR fridge appliance could cut your CO2 emissions by around 48kg per year and save you around £13.
links: <link><linktext>Energy Saving Recommended products are the most efficient in their category, click here to find one:</linktext><linkurl>http://www.energysavingtrust.org.uk/energy_saving_products  </linkurl></link>

content:
The facts

Your freezer is one of the biggest energy consumers in your house as it?s on the go 24 hours a day, 7 days a week. 
If everyone in the UK swapped to an Energy Saving Recommended (ESR) version we could save around �800 million and 2.8 million tonnes CO2.

What you can do

Have you ever thought about replacing your old freezer with a new ESR model? It could save around 50% of the energy you are using, 85kg of CO2 per year and will also reduce your electricity bill.
links: <link><linktext>Energy Saving Recommended products are the most efficient in their category, click here to find one:</linktext><linkurl>http://www.energysavingtrust.org.uk/energy_saving_products  </linkurl></link>

content:
The facts
Your fridge-freezer is one of the biggest energy consumers in your house as it's on the go 24 hours a day, 7 days a week. 
If everyone in the UK swapped to an Energy Saving Recommended (ESR) version we could save around ?800 million and 2.8 million tonnes CO2.

What you can do
Have you thought about replacing your old fridge-freezer with a new Energy Saving Recommended model?  It could save around 50% of the energy used by your old appliance, cut 143kg of CO2 per year and could reduce your electricity bill.

If you are in the market for a new fridge-freezer, it pays to be wary of frost-free fridge-freezers as they generally use up to 50% more energy to run than non-frost free versions.
briefTipContent: Consider replacing your fridge-freezer with a more efficient model
links: <link><linktext>Energy Saving Recommended products are the most efficient in their category, click here to find one:</linktext><linkurl>http://www.energysavingtrust.org.uk/energy_saving_products  </linkurl></link>

content:
The facts
Microwaves are now a staple in many UK kitchens. Besides being very convenient, they’re also more energy efficient than a traditional oven as they cook food much more quickly.

What you can do
If you already own a microwave try to use it instead of your oven or hob wherever possible –the instruction manual for your microwave will have guidelines on how to get the most out of it.
briefTipContent: Consider using your microwave more frequently

content:
The facts
Microwaves are now a staple in many UK kitchens, not only used for convenience foods, they?re now also deemed more energy efficient than your oven as they cook food so much more quickly. 

What you can do
Have you thought about investing in a microwave? They?ll save you energy as they use significantly less than your conventional oven or hob.
briefTipContent: Consider investing in a microwave

content:
The facts
Kettles are one of the most used appliances in your kitchen, with the average family boiling theirs 4 times a day. And heating water uses a large amount of electricity, so if you?re boiling more than you need you?re wasting a lot of energy ? and money. 

What you can do 
When you?re using the kettle, only boil as much water as you actually need. If every UK household only boiled enough water for one cup of tea, instead of filling the kettle to the brim each time they wanted a single cuppa, we could save 670,000 tonnes of CO2 a year!
briefTipContent: Only fill the kettle to the required level
links: <link><linktext>Check the Energy Saving Trust's simple tips for other ideas like this:</linktext><linkurl>http://www.energysavingtrust.org.uk/what_can_i_do_today/cheap_and_simple_tips </linkurl></link>

content:
The facts
It may come as a surprise to you, but using a dishwasher can actually be more energy efficient than doing the washing up by hand . If, for example, you do many small bowlfuls of washing up every day, then that can use more energy than running a dishwasher, provided it’s an energy efficient model and is fully loaded. Modern dishwashers can use as little as 15 litres of water to wash a full load of dishes - so you can save water too. 

What you can do
If you are thinking of buying a dishwasher, always look for the Energy Saving Recommended logo.  An ESR one can cost around £47 less to run over its lifetime than an average one.
briefTipContent: Consider investing in an A-rated dishwasher
links: <link><linktext>Pay less for clean dishes.  Find an Energy Saving Recommended dishwasher:</linktext><linkurl>http://www.energysavingtrust.org.uk/energy_saving_products/types_of_energy_saving_recommended_products/dishwashers </linkurl></link>

content:
The facts
It may come as a surprise to you, but as you are already using a dishwasher, your CO2 emissions may be lower than another household that hand washes their dishes. A dishwasher can be more energy efficient than lots of bowls of hand-washing, if used in the right way. But there are still ways to make more savings...

What you can do 
Every time you use your dishwasher make sure that it’s fully-loaded, so that you’re not wasting energy on washing empty space. You should also try to use the more energy efficient economy settings or cooler wash cycles whenever possible. Finally, if you’re in the market for a new dishwasher, investing in an Energy Saving Recommended (ESR) appliance could save around 65kg of CO2 and %A323 in running costs per year.
briefTipContent: Fill your dishwasher up fully and use the economy setting more frequently
links: <link><linktext>Energy Saving Recommended products are the most efficient in their category, click here to find one:</linktext><linkurl>http://www.energysavingtrust.org.uk/energy_saving_products</linkurl></link>

content:
The facts 
Keeping our clothes fresh and clean has become less of chore thanks to machines that clean our clothes and banish every stain going, but this can often come at a cost. The average household runs 274 cycles of laundry a year and as you have a washing machine with a B rating or below, you could start saving money and emissions if you made an upgrade to an A or A+ model. 

What you can do
By upgrading your machine to an Energy Saving Recommended (ESR) appliance you could save around 32kg of CO2 a year and, as a bonus, you’ll cut your water consumption too. To start reducing your washing machine’s CO2 emissions right now: make sure that you always use the more energy efficient economy settings; run shorter, cooler wash cycles whenever possible (with modern detergents 30°C is fine for most washes); and make sure that you do full loads every time you wash.
briefTipContent: Consider replacing your washing machine with a top rated/Energy Saving Recommended model
links: <link><linktext>Energy Saving Recommended washing machines use a third less energy:</linktext><linkurl>http://www.energysavingtrust.org.uk/energy_saving_products/types_of_energy_saving_recommended_products/laundry_appliances </linkurl></link>

content:
Great news
You already own one of the most efficient washing machines on the market, which means you’re saving around 32kg of CO2 each year compared to a less efficient old model.  But don’t forget to do full loads for each wash, on the economy setting, and turn to 30°C whenever possible, so you save even more!
briefTipContent: Thank you for investing in a top rated washing machine
links: <link><linktext>If you are thinking about buying other energy saving products click here:</linktext><linkurl>http://www.energysavingtrust.org.uk/energy_saving_products </linkurl></link>

content:
The facts 
Keeping our clothes fresh and clean has become less of chore thanks to machines that clean our clothes and banish every stain going. The average household runs 274 cycles a year, often at 60˚C or higher, but this can be reduced to save you money and emissions.

What you can do 
Using a 40°C wash cycle uses around 40% less energy than at 60˚C, and if you reduce the wash temperature even further to a 30°C cycle for lightly soiled / ‘worn once’ garments, the amount of energy saved will be even higher.
briefTipContent: Wash clothes at low (30/40 degree) temperatures whenever possible

content:
The facts 
Almost 60% of UK households now use a tumble drier instead of drying their clothes outside. While it may seem convenient, an average cycle emits 1.3kg of CO2, and makes your carbon footprint bigger than it could be.

What you can do
It’s tempting to throw your wet clothes in the drier, but you could get much fresher and often faster results from line drying. If the weather isn’t great, invest in a drying rack which can be put up inside. If you do need to tumble dry, consider replacing your existing tumble dryer with a heat pump dryer. They’re up to 25% more energy efficient than conventional electric dryers, typically save up to 45 kg CO2 per year and best of all, they’ll also reduce your electricity bill.
briefTipContent: In dry weather use an outside line rather than your dryer (assume 4 months per year)

content:
What you can do
It’s tempting to throw your wet clothes in the drier, but you could get much fresher and often faster results from line drying. If the weather isn’t great, invest in a drying rack which can be put up inside. If you do need to tumble dry, consider replacing your existing tumble dryer with a heat pump dryer
links: <link><linktext>Find Energy Saving Recommended products:</linktext><linkurl>http://www.energysavingtrust.org.uk/energy_saving_products</linkurl></link>

content:
The facts

TVs are now part of the furniture in most households, with one in the living room and often another in the kitchen and/or bedroom. They can use a lot of energy, and are often left on standby, so it’s worth making sure you’re using them efficiently.
 
What you can do
When you buy a new TV look for the Energy Saving Recommended (ESR) label, this will mean you are sure of buying the most efficient TV in its class. Also, your new TV might come with much brighter settings than needed for your living room, so you can save money and cut CO2 emissions by turning the brightness and contrast down to a comfortable level.   Remember always to switch your TV off completely when you have finished watching, either using the ‘off’ button on the TV itself or by switching it off at the wall.
briefTipContent: Turn the brightness and contrast down on brand new TVs

The facts

content: TIP NEEEDS TO BE REMOVED

The facts 

Although digital radios are great for their wide variety of music stations, they can use up to 5 times more energy than analogue radios. 
What you can do
If you are in the market for a new digital radio, look for the Energy Saving Recommended (ESR) label, this will ensure you are buying a radio that uses minimum energy.  Make sure your digital radio is always switched off completely at the wall, rather than leaving it on standby.
briefTipContent: Switch your digital radio off at the plug when not in use

content:
The facts
Across the UK we waste the equivalent of nearly one power stations? worth of electricity each year simply by leaving our appliances on standby mode. 

What you can do 
if everyone avoided standby we could save up to %A3900 million per year and save 1.6 million tonnes of CO2 a year.
briefTipContent: Avoid leaving electrical appliances and equipment on stand-by

content:
Great news
If you never leave your entertainment equipment on stand-by, and you switch everything off properly, you are saving yourself around £37 each year, and reducing your CO2 emissions
briefTipContent: Thank you for avoiding leaving electrical equipment on standy-by
links: <link><linktext>Click here to see other energy saving tips you can do today:</linktext><linkurl>http://www.energysavingtrust.org.uk/what_can_i_do_today/cheap_and_simple_tips </linkurl></link>

content:
Great news 
You never leave power supply plugs on stand-by. Power supply plugs are the bulky style ones used for mobile phones or laptop chargers, and they continue to consume energy when not charging, but by turning yours right off, you’re saving money and reducing your CO2 emissions.
briefTipContent: Thank you for not leaving charging plugs on when not in use.
links: <link><linktext>Click here to see other energy saving tips you can do today:</linktext><linkurl>http://www.energysavingtrust.org.uk/what_can_i_do_today/cheap_and_simple_tips </linkurl></link>

content:
The facts
If every household in the UK leaves just one mobile phone charger plugged in each time they charge up their phone, that wastes over %A35.8 million, and results in almost a quarter of a million additional tonnes of CO2. 

What you can do
You can reduce your CO2 emissions by turning the charger off at the wall once your electrical items are recharged. If you have chargers or other power supplies that are turned on at the wall socket they will still use energy regardless of if they are charging something or not.
icon: 9 or more PSU image (power supplies plugged in
briefTipContent: Avoid leaving phone chargers and other external power supply plugs turned on when not in use.
links: <link><linktext>Click here to see other energy saving tips you can do today:</linktext><linkurl>http://www.energysavingtrust.org.uk/what_can_i_do_today/cheap_and_simple_tips </linkurl></link>

content:
Great news 
Choosing a laptop instead of a desktop is the wise energy choice.  A new laptop, on average, consumes around 15% of the power of a new desktop, whilst in ‘on’ mode.
briefTipContent: By using a laptop instead of a desk top you are reducing your emissions.

content:
The facts
Demand for electricity to power computers has doubled in the past few years, with the average household owning at least one computer, these tend to be the older ?desktop? model that emit more CO2 than new efficient laptops.

What you can do
If you are thinking of buying a new computer consider choosing a laptop over a desktop, they are much more efficient in their consumption of energy, using only around 15% of a desktop?s energy consumption.
briefTipContent: When buying computer, consider choosing a laptop instead of a desktop model

content:
The facts
As a nation we own an estimated 18.5 million printers, And they tend to be left on all the time even though we often use them for just a few minutes a day.  All printers use electricity in every mode, apart from when  they?re switched off, so try to consider when you really need to have yours switched on.

What you can do 
If you have a choice of printers (especially in the office), avoid using a laser printer for draft-quality printouts. From an energy efficiency perspective, the order of preference should be inkj
briefTipContent: Choose more efficient printers and use 'eco' functions for draft/personal material

content:
The facts 
Across the UK we waste enough electricity to power two power stations each year, just by leaving our appliances on standby mode. 

What you can do 
Always remember to turn your PC, printer and other gadgets off properly when you have finished using them. PCs in particular use a significant amount of energy when left in idle mode (on, but not in use), but significantly less in Sleep mode.  Try to adjust your PC power management settings to ensure that if they are left on by accident they automatically go into Sleepmode after a period of time.  Often PCs and printers are left in stand-by mode overnight or when no one is in the house, so remember to turn them right off at the plug to save the most money and CO2.
briefTipContent: Avoid leaving computers and their peripherals on stand-by when not in use

content:
Great news
If you never leave PC equipment on stand-by and you switch everything off, you are saving yourself around money while reducing your CO2 emissions.

content:
Great news 
As you don’t own a motorcycle or car, you’ve reduced your footprint by around 3 tonnes, compared to the average household footprint.

Great news
You own a car with a small engine, which means it emits much less CO2.  When choosing a new car, always go for the lowest CO2 emitting version and you’ll reduce your fuel consumption by up to 24%.
links: <link><linktext>Are you a smarter driver%3F Take the test to find out:</linktext><linkurl>http://www.energysavingtrust.org.uk/what_can_i_do_today/Smarter-driving/eco_driving_quiz  </linkurl></link>

content:
The facts
In the UK, the road transport sector produces around a quarter of the CO 2 emissions, with nearly 60 per cent coming from passenger cars, and although sometimes there is no way round not having a car, we can do more to reduce our CO2 emissions in this sector.

What you can do 
Consider choosing a lower CO2 emitting car when you replace yours. Buying the lowest CO2 car within a car category (eg family car, estate, MPV, etc) can reduce your CO2 emissions and therefore fuel consumption by up to 24%. For help choosing a lower CO2 car, search online for Act on CO2 - http://campaigns.direct.gov.uk/actonco2/home/on-the-move/top-10-fuel-efficient-cars.html
briefTipContent: When replacing your car, consider choosing the lowest CO2 model in its category
links: <link><linktext>Are you a smarter driver%3F Take the test to find out:</linktext><linkurl>http://www.energysavingtrust.org.uk/what_can_i_do_today/Smarter-driving/eco_driving_quiz  </linkurl></link>

content:
The facts
In the UK, the road transport sector produces around a quarter of the CO 2 emissions, with nearly 60 per cent coming from passenger cars, and although sometimes there is no way round not using your car, there are other ways of getting around that will help to reduce CO2.

What you can do
As you clock up quite a few miles per year, have you thought about using other ways of getting around, especially for shorter journeys? If you can, try to walk, ride a bike, car share, or use public transport. Every litre of fuel you save reduces the amount of CO2 emissions that are released into the atmosphere and your carbon footprint.
briefTipContent: Whenever possible, walk, bike, car share, or use public transport.
links: <link><linktext>Reduce your fuel costs by following some simple smarter driving tips:</linktext><linkurl>http://www.energysavingtrust.org.uk/what_can_i_do_today/Smarter-driving </linkurl></link>

content:
Great news 
Your yearly car mileage is around half that of the average UK citizen.  By using your car less you are saving up to 2 tonnes of CO2 per annum.
links: <link><linktext>Click here if you would like to know about other means of transport:</linktext><linkurl>http://www.energysavingtrust.org.uk/What-can-I-do-today/Smarter-driving/Using-alternative-transport </linkurl></link>

content:
The facts
Low tyre pressure, a dirty air filter or a cluttered car can all increase the amount of CO2 you emit. These factors reduce your vehicles efficiency, which means it has to work harder and use more fuel on every journey. 

What you can do 
Make sure you keep your vehicle well tuned. Taking it in for a regular service will keep it running at its best, whilst saving you money, fuel and reducing your CO2 emissions.
briefTipContent: Keep your vehicle well maintained
links: <link><linktext>Reduce your fuel costs by following some simple smarter driving tips:</linktext><linkurl>http://www.energysavingtrust.org.uk/what_can_i_do_today/Smarter-driving </linkurl></link>

content:
The facts
Under-inflated tyres create more resistance when your car is moving. The engine has to work harder, more fuel is used and as a result more CO2 is emitted.

What you can do
Check and adjust your tyres regularly. Correctly inflated tyres are safer, last longer and help to reduce your CO2 emissions. If you’re unsure of the correct tyre pressure for your car, check your manual or visit your local engineer who will be able to talk you through it.
briefTipContent: It is important to check your tyre pressures regularly.
links: <link><linktext>Reduce your fuel costs by following some simple smarter driving tips:</linktext><linkurl>http://www.energysavingtrust.org.uk/what_can_i_do_today/Smarter-driving </linkurl></link>

content:
The facts 
In the UK, the road transport sector produces around a quarter of the CO 2 emissions, with nearly 60 per cent coming from passenger cars. Just by driving your car in a more considered way, you could reduce your CO2 emissions, the amount of fuel you use, and your own personal footprint. 

What you can do 
Avoid erratic braking and accelerating, this uses more fuel that just driving at a consistent speed. Drive at a good distance from the car in front, so you can anticipate and travel with the flow of traffic. Keep to within the speed limit, this increases driver safety, reduces CO2 emissions and saves money on your petrol costs.
briefTipContent: Try to adopt a smoother driving style and avoid exessive speed.
links: <link><linktext>Reduce your fuel costs by following some simple smarter driving tips:</linktext><linkurl>http://www.energysavingtrust.org.uk/what_can_i_do_today/Smarter-driving </linkurl></link>

content:
The facts
Road transport accounts for 22% of all UK domestic CO2 emissions (excluding international aviation and shipping). Using your own car for every journey, short or long, increases the amount of CO2 pumped into our air, so try to use public transport whenever you can.

What you can do 
Using public transport means that there are fewer cars on the road emitting CO2. There is often a range of options available to you in your area, and it costs very little money. Plus it will reduce traffic congestion and as well as helping to lower the country’s CO2 emissions as well.
briefTipContent: Try to make more use of public transport where possible.
links: <link><linktext>Have you tried the Transportdirect travel planner to explore your different travel options for your journey%3F  It will also show you the CO2 impact of the different options.</linktext><linkurl>http://www.transportdirect.info </linkurl></link>

content:
Great news
As you use public transport regularly, you’re cutting your own CO2 emissions, as well as reducing congestion and pollution on the road.
links: <link><linktext>Have you tried the Transportdirect travel planner to explore your different travel options for your journey%3F  It will also show you the CO2 impact of the different options.</linktext><linkurl>http://www.transportdirect.info </linkurl></link>

content:
Air conditioning in cars increases fuel consumption, by not using it you can improve your consumption by between 5 and 25%.  

What you can do
If it’s really hot outside and you’re driving at speeds above 50-60mph, it’s more fuel efficient to use your air con rather than opening your windows. At this speed open windows create drag on your car, which means your engine has to work harder and uses more fuel. If you do need a bit of air, try using ordinary fan heaters or coolers as they generally have a lower impact on fuel consumption.
briefTipContent: Try to minimise the use of air conditioning.
links: <link><linktext>Reduce your fuel costs by following some simple smarter driving tips:</linktext><linkurl>http://www.energysavingtrust.org.uk/what_can_i_do_today/Smarter-driving </linkurl></link>

content:
The facts
Air conditioning in cars increases fuel consumption, by keeping it switched off you can improve your consumption by between 5 and 25%.  

What you can do
Try to reduce your air con use. However if it’s really hot outside and you’re driving at speeds above 50-60mph, it’s more fuel efficient to use it rather than opening your windows. Open windows at this speed create drag on your car, which means your engine has to work harder and uses more fuel.
links: <link><linktext>Reduce your fuel costs by following some simple smarter driving tips:</linktext><linkurl>http://www.energysavingtrust.org.uk/what_can_i_do_today/Smarter-driving </linkurl></link>

content:
The facts 
Nearly 25% of car journeys are less than 2 miles, this considering cars consume most fuel at the start of their journey, means that the majority of the short journeys you make in your car are emitting more CO2 gas than usual. 

What you can do 
Walking or cycling for short journeys is not only good for your health but could also reduce your carbon footprint.  Just walking or cycling your children a mile to and from school each day would save 280 kg of CO2 each year compared to the journey in an average car.
briefTipContent: Try to avoid using your car for short journeys - walking or cycling can be good alternatives.
links: <link><linktext>Reduce your fuel costs by following some simple smarter driving tips:</linktext><linkurl>http://www.energysavingtrust.org.uk/what_can_i_do_today/Smarter-driving </linkurl></link>

content:
Great news
As you already taking short journeys by foot or bike, you’re reducing CO2, saving money and best of all, improving your health.
links: <link><linktext>Reduce your fuel costs by following some simple smarter driving tips:</linktext><linkurl>http://www.energysavingtrust.org.uk/what_can_i_do_today/Smarter-driving </linkurl></link>

content:
The facts
Car sharing is when two or more people travel in a car for a journey together. It not only reduces your CO2 emissions, but means you can share the costs of fuel, parking and wear and tear on the vehicle. Car sharing with just one person will reduce your emissions by half and with four people this rises to three-quarters.

What you can do
Think about times that you could car share, maybe to and from work with a colleague, to business meetings or when you’re taking a longer journey to visit family and friends, or to a holiday destination.  Not only is car sharing a great way to help reduce your CO2 emissions, it’s also a great way to save you money as well.
briefTipContent: Try to avoid using several vehicles and  car-share for journeys where-ever possible
links: <link><linktext>Reduce your fuel costs by following some simple smarter driving tips:</linktext><linkurl>http://www.energysavingtrust.org.uk/what_can_i_do_today/Smarter-driving </linkurl></link>

content:
The facts
Air travel now accounts for 6.3% of the UK’s total CO2 emissions, and as a whole, scientific research has proven, that its non CO2 emissions also affects our environment 2-4 times more due to its radiative forcing (the expulsion of water vapour and nitrogen oxide). 

What you can do
Instead of flying, consider holidays that you can travel to by car, or for business meetings try to share your car journey with a colleague. If you do really need to fly, then try to offset the CO2 you’ll expel in flight and use public transport to and from the airport.
briefTipContent: Air travel is making a growing contribution to CO2 emissions.

content:
The facts
Air travel now accounts for 6.3% of the UK’s total CO2 emissions, and as a whole, scientific research has proven, that its non CO2 emissions also affects our environment 2-4 times more due to its radiative forcing (the expulsion of water vapour and nitrogen oxide). 

What you can do
Instead of flying, consider travelling by rail or car. On average travelling by rail will result in about a third of the CO2 emissions of the equivalent domestic or short-haul flight in Europe. A similar journey for two people in an average-sized car would save around 40% CO2 emissions.
briefTipContent: Consider the need for a flight and the alternatives to taking a plane.

content:
The facts
Air travel now accounts for 6.3% of the UK’s total CO2 emissions, and as a whole, scientific research has proven, that its non CO2 emissions also affects our environment 2-4 times more due to its radiative forcing (the expulsion of water vapour and nitrogen oxide).
Just one long haul return flight can give you the same (or larger) footprint as driving a car for an entire year.  

What you can do
Think about taking holidays closer to home that you could drive or take a train to. For example, if you and a partner flew to Italy instead of Australia for a holiday you could save 7.52 tonnes of CO2.
briefTipContent: Just one long haul return flight can give a footprint similar to a years use for a typical car.
